Award.AwardTitle: Dynamical Processes in Strongly Coupled Complex Plasmas
Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex (dusty) plasmas consist of mesoscopic grains immersed in the background of a gaseous plasma of electrons, ions and neutral atoms. The grains become highly charged, collecting electric charges up to 10000 times the electronic charge and acquiring a high level of potential energy. As a result, they become strongly coupled, i. e. their dynamics becomes governed by their potential, rather than their kinetic energy. In this state, the behavior of the grains largely mimics, albeit on a different scale, many of the physical processes that atoms and molecules undergo in condensed matter. This project addresses the dynamical behavior of complex plasmas through theoretical analysis combined with computer simulation. As such, it represents a novel approach to problems associated with issues in areas of condensed matter physics, by studying processes similar to those occurring in solids, liquids, etc. on a "magnified" scale where direct visual observation is possible. This approach requires that the investigators possess a broad overview of many different areas of physics. A special intellectual merit of the project is the use of a unique analytic method, created some time ago by the Principal Investigator and his colleagues, This method, referred to as the Quasi Localized Charge Approximation, was already tested in earlier funding periods where it provided interpretations of a variety of laboratory experiments and computer simulations.

Complex (dusty) plasmas occur in a variety of natural situations. Examples are various astrophysical systems, the Earth's environment, gas discharges, semiconductor processing facilities, etc. In addition, laboratory experiments and experiments in gravitation free environment in the orbiting Space Station produce these strongly coupled plasmas as well: from the experimental point of view these systems are unique in that they combine properties of conventional plasmas and (liquid and solid) condensed matter. This is a key feature that provides the opportunity to study properties of various highly dissimilar physical system, such as colloids, stellar interiors, magnets, cryogenic "ultracold" systems and extremely hot and dense matter created in particle accelerators under macroscopic "visible" experimental conditions. The major computer simulation program of the project will open broad opportunities for students in training and practicing in computational methods. Participating students will be encouraged to visit US and overseas laboratories and training programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this Award was to investigate basic properties of dusty plasmas.

 

Dusty plasmas are collections of mesoscopic particles (a few microns in diameter, surrounded by a normal plasma , which consists of electrons and ions). When the rapidly moving fast electrons hit the surface of the grain they get absorbed and impart their charge to the grain . By doing so they charge the grains to a very high value, several thousand times the electronic charge. This feature makes the grains strongly interacting, i. e. their electrostatic interaction energy vastly surpasses their kinetic energy. It is this particular feature that makes the study of dusty plasmas very different from works on ordinary plasmas. Such investigations require special theoretical approaches, adapted to the different situation.

 

Dusty plasmas occur in many natural and laboratory settings. In astrophysics, they are probably the main constituents of the rings of Saturn, which is currently a major research target of the NASA spacecraft CASSINI.  Quite differently, in industrial settings, dusty plasmas play a crucial role in etching of semiconductor surfaces in the process of computer chip manufacturing. In addition, dusty plasmas offer the promise that in conjunction with nano-technology they can pave the way for the fabrication of completely novel materials (diamond films, e.g.)

 

Since the constituents of  dusty plasmas  have a size immensely large than the size of an atom, their behavior can be studied by direct visual observation, quite in contrast to any other many particle condensed matter systems. At the same time, their dynamics is governed by the same laws as that of systems whose constituent are too small for direct observation. Therefor dusty plasmas provide an excellent ”enlarged ” model for the analysis of what happens in real solids and liquids under various circumstances.

 

As mentioned above, the study of dusty plasmas requires special theoretical methods. One of such methods, baptized as Quasi Localized Charge Approximation  (QLCA) was created under earlier NSF Awards, by the PI and his collaborators. Activities under the present Award were focused on studying wave-like phenomena  through the application of this method. In particular, we have studied the following issues:

(i)                         When dusty plasmas interact with beams of ions, unavoidable in the usual laboratory setup, how does this interaction affect the stability of the system?

(ii)                     Grains in the dusty plasma may acquire  (or may be made to acquire) a magnetic moment, which  brings about a much more complex behavior than otherwise. We studied this behavior  and found that it leads to the formation of various macroscopic structures (stripes, islands, etc.) and in this respect it emulates what happens in actual  magnetic condensed matter system We also analyzed wave propagation under such circumstances.

(iii)                  We launched a long range program to study basic properties of dusty plasmas consisting of a mixture of differently sized grains. Such a system is an excellent model for various liquids that occur in Nature.

All our investigations were done in collaboration with a research group of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences in Budapest, Hungary.  This group has unique expertise in computer simulation of plasma. Their work served to complement and check the validity of the theoretical models we had used. This collaboration has led to an ongoing training of students in computational technique in the Budapest Institute
